articles.headline: Loosening the Rules on Insider Trading
articles.snippet: An appellate court seems inclined to change the rules on insider trading in a way that will make it easier for professional traders to escape liability.
articles.abstract: An appellate court seems inclined to change the rules on insider trading in a way that will make it easier for professional traders to escape liability.
articles.lead_paragraph: Insider trading laws used to be for amateurs. Professional traders knew how to avoid being caught.

articles.headline: Why the Housing Market Is Still Stalling the Economy
articles.snippet: Millions are living with parents or friends and just not setting up households.
articles.abstract: Millions are living with parents or friends and just not setting up households.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the economy still feels stuck, blame the housing market.

articles.headline: Digital Mapping May Be Nokia’s Hidden Jewel
articles.snippet: Though a laggard in smartphone location apps, Nokia’s Here mapping system is a leader in car navigation and might be a tantalizing takeover target.
articles.abstract: Though a laggard in smartphone location apps, Nokia’s Here mapping system is a leader in car navigation and might be a tantalizing takeover target.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For the first time in more than three decades, Nokia faces the future without being a player in the global phone business. On Friday, the company completes the sale of its beleaguered handset business to Microsoft for $7.5 billion.

articles.headline: Tech Giants Settle Antitrust Hiring Suit
articles.snippet: Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe reached an agreement with plaintiffs over charges that the companies conspired not to hire one another’s employees.
articles.abstract: Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe reached an agreement with plaintiffs over charges that the companies conspired not to hire one another’s employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The workers of Silicon Valley have won an important victory over their bosses. What they did not win is a lot of money.

articles.headline: For E-Cigarettes, the Regulatory Battle Now Begins
articles.snippet: Proposed rules postponed tricky issues like whether flavors should be banned or television advertising limited.
articles.abstract: Proposed rules postponed tricky issues like whether flavors should be banned or television advertising limited.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At last, Washington is moving to police the multibillion-dollar business of electronic cigarettes.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Barry Meier

articles.headline: Rand Paul and Wealthy Libertarians Connect as He Weighs Running
articles.snippet: Mr. Paul is reaching out to people who have largely donated their money to nonprofit groups and colleges, not to politicians.
articles.abstract: Mr. Paul is reaching out to people who have largely donated their money to nonprofit groups and colleges, not to politicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: Frayda Levin, a New Jersey libertarian activist and former small-business owner, is a woman of many passions: promoting liberty, ending marijuana prohibition and opposing her state’s recent minimum-wage increase. But Ms. Levin has added another cause as well. At gala benefits for free-market research institutes and at fund-raisers for antitax groups, she has urged like-minded donors to help send Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, to the White House.

articles.headline: In Florida Tomato Fields, a Penny Buys Progress
articles.snippet: A group of dedicated farmworkers enlisted companies like McDonald’s, Walmart and Yum Brands to press tomato growers for better conditions.
articles.abstract: A group of dedicated farmworkers enlisted companies like McDonald’s, Walmart and Yum Brands to press tomato growers for better conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: IMMOKALEE, Fla. — Not long ago, Angelina Velasquez trudged to a parking lot at 5 each morning so a crew leader’s bus could drop her at the tomato fields by 6. She often waited there, unpaid — while the dew dried — until 10 a.m., when the workers were told to clock in and start picking.

articles.headline: Lobbying Efforts Intensify After F.C.C. Tries 3rd Time on Net Neutrality
articles.snippet: The sparring will be closely watched by every company that depends, even peripherally, on the Internet — which is to say, just about every company.
articles.abstract: The sparring will be closely watched by every company that depends, even peripherally, on the Internet — which is to say, just about every company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the nine weeks since the Federal Communications Commission said it would try, for a third time, to write new rules to secure an open Internet, at least 69 companies, interest groups and trade associations — over one a day — have met with or otherwise lobbied commission officials on what the rules should specify.

articles.headline: Alternative to Pap Test Is Approved by F.D.A.
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new primary method for detecting cervical cancer developed by the pharmaceutical company Roche.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new primary method for detecting cervical cancer developed by the pharmaceutical company Roche.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first alternative to the long-used Pap test as a primary screening method for cervical cancer, in the face of opposition from some women’s groups and health organizations.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Seeks Mortgage Deal With Bank of America
articles.snippet: The Justice Department made Bank of America an opening settlement offer of roughly $20 billion several weeks ago, according to people briefed on the matter.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department made Bank of America an opening settlement offer of roughly $20 billion several weeks ago, according to people briefed on the matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department, building on a multibillion-dollar mortgage settlement with JPMorgan Chase last year, is now aiming for a deal with Bank of America.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess
